Award.AwardTitle: Adapting the Next Generation Physical Science and Everyday Thinking curriculum for a lecture-laboratory format (Adapting Next Gen PET)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Exploration and Design for Engaged Student Learning project seeks to address two persistent problems in undergraduate education: the challenge of effective teaching resulting in useful learning in large lecture formats and the challenge of developing scientific understanding of physics principles by pre-service elementary teacher candidates. Adapting Next Gen PET strives to improve physics learning for future teachers while empowering faculty to implement education research in their physics courses by providing a well-tested and refined version of the curriculum that fits the most widely used general education science class model (lecture and lab) and can make full use of the rich supporting faculty resources developed for Physics and Everyday Thinking and Learning Physical Science. The Next Generation Physical Science and Everyday Thinking (Next Gen PET) grew from Physics and Everyday Thinking (PET), which has been shown to significantly affect both future teacher content knowledge and understanding of how students learn science. It has been taught at two-year and four-year institutions, adapted for science methods courses, and offered as a workshop for practicing elementary teachers. And yet, it does not fit the common lecture/lab format that fulfills general education requirements at most colleges. This project will develop an implementation outline of existing materials to support the lecture/lab model and add the one science practice which is currently unsupported: Planning and Carrying Out Investigations. Upon completion, a national workshop will be advertised to the Physics Teacher Education Coalition (PhysTEC) institutions and to all physics departments in the U.S. This project will not only provide a course appropriate for adoption by PhysTEC institutions, but also one that could serve as a general education natural science lab course for a broad range of non-STEM majors. Outcomes of this project will be the development of undergraduate students with an increased understanding of how scientists discover and build knowledge, learn science themselves, and learn how to better teach science to others (for example, elementary school students). The materials would be designed to support faculty in implementing research-based instructional practices, which could catalyze faculty transition to using these effective methods more broadly.

The Adapting Next Gen PET project builds upon prior work and will: develop instructional activities and an investigation practice assessment instrument; infuse the materials into a current course and validate the new assessment instrument with pre-service elementary teacher candidates; and enter into a reiterative process of revision and implementation based on the student and faculty instructor feedback and project evaluation. This project will carefully map and test an implementation schedule that utilizes existing materials with additional activities focusing on the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) practices least well covered by the current curricula, particularly Planning and Carrying Out Investigations. The careful mapping to maximize coherent story lines will also identify where in the course the best opportunities for enhancing experimental design may exist. Several large-class-setting lessons, as well as a complementary laboratory component, will be added. Testing will ensure that no loss of learning or attitude improvement compared to the existing materials result from the new structure. Additionally, the assessment process will lead to more appropriate instruments for measuring students' knowledge of the Planning and Carrying Out Investigations practice, which is critically important to pre-service teachers' pedagogical disciplinary knowledge. The knowledge and skills pre-service teachers learn and practice in the course will help them become effective teachers of science. Designed from both the constructivist and social-cultural theoretical perspectives and built on a conceptual change framework, this project has the potential to influence future elementary teachers, as well as future high school teachers assisting in the course, and it will afford the opportunity to introduce more faculty to research-based curricula and pedagogy. As the course supports will not be too far removed from traditional instruction and will not require that faculty rewrite curriculum, faculty will have the opportunity to explore and practice using interactive pedagogy that allows for student construction of ideas, possibly supporting faculty transition to and advocacy for research-based instructional practices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project:

1. Developed an implementation outline of existing materials to support the Next Generation Physical Science and Everyday Thinking (Next Gen PET) lecture/lab model (hybrid structure).

The flexible implementation outline developed supports a lecture/lab structure for Next Gen PET (https://nextgenpet.activatelearning.com). A discussion of hybrid implementation appears on its own page, and is referenced from all other relevant locations within the site. Since pedagogical thinking is built into the materials' design, using them helps prompt research-based instructional practices. The materials are modular and flexible, empowering instructors with minimal background to teach in pedagogically effective ways. The hybrid course proved equivalent to Next Gen PET for supporting pre-service elementary teachers' learning of science.

2. Added additional curricular activities focusing on the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) practice least well covered by the current curricula: Planning and Carrying Out Investigations (PCOI) (also called Planning and Conducting Investigations (PCI).

Because the Next Gen PET website is designed to both facilitate implementation and support those purchasing the Next Gen PET curricular materials, the freely available PCI materials developed during this project are distributed through a separate linked website linked (https://nextgenpet.activatelearning.com/studio-style-class/pci-activities-and-extensions). The site describes them:

"Because Next Gen PET was developed to be explicitly aligned with [NGSS], it is a model curriculum for these standards. It exemplifies three-dimensional learning with core content ideas in the physical sciences, as well as scientific practices and crosscutting concepts.

The NGSS alignment is nearly complete in the core materials for Next Gen PET. However, with respect to NGSS Practice 3, [PCOI], even though students have many opportunities to carry out investigations throughout the curriculum, they do not have opportunities to plan or design their own investigations. With that in mind, the goal of this optional set of activities is to add activities that support this entire practice. The design is meant to be consistent with the existing materials, but with as much flexibility as possible. The materials as presented are designed for the Studio-style setting and can be used freely by just downloading them from this site.

The materials were written with the support of the National Science Foundation grant NSF DUE-1611738 by Dr. Paul Miller at West Virginia University. If you choose to use these activities, suggestions and feedback are welcome."

3. Provided a workshop advertised to the Physics Teacher Education Coalition (PhysTEC) institutions and all U.S. physics departments to encourage implementation of this curriculum, supporting faculty in implementing research-based instructional practices.

Two workshops presented the hybrid-model of the NextGen PET at the PhysTEC 2018 meeting in College Park, Maryland:

A one-day workshop "Adapting the Next Generation Physical Science and Everyday Thinking suite of curriculum materials for your own course(s)" was presented by Paul Miller (West Virginia University), Ed Price (California State University San Marcos), and Steve Robinson (Tennessee Technological University). Participants learned about an NGSS-based course for prospective elementary teachers using the comprehensive, flexible set of Next Gen PET materials for students and instructors. These materials have been prepared for small lab style (Studio) courses and large (Lecture-only) courses. The theme of the workshop was flexible implementation, and the new Hybrid implementation that fully supports a general education lecture/lab schedule was also presented.

A shorter workshop, "Next Generation Physical Science and Everyday Thinking (Next Gen PET)" was presented by the same instructors. This workshop featured the hybrid implementation and PCI materials and included many hands-on activities.

4. Developed an appropriate instrument for measuring students' knowledge of the PCOI practice, which is critically important to pre-service teachers' pedagogical disciplinary knowledge.

Instrument construction began by examining the NGSS Practice 3, PCOI and its Sub-dimensions for 3rd-8th grade students. Each item is mapped to the Sub-dimension Abilities. To make administering the assessment in class possible and avoid test fatigue, for some sub-dimensions there are only one or two corresponding items, and some items correspond to more than one sub-dimension. Three physics professors and a science educator answered each item and identified which sub-dimension(s) they believed each item assessed. Items were then revised according to recommendations. The resulting instrument was administered to preservice teachers; post-administration, semi-structured interviews examined student rationale for their responses. Revisions to items were made as needed based on interview responses.

The resulting 22-item instrument was administered to more than 2000 students, allowing instrument validation. Validation included calculating item difficulty; only four items were at or outside of the ideal range. All were too easy, indicating ceiling effects. The PCOI instrument is now ready for distribution and additional testing.

Broader Impacts:

The hybrid (lecture/lab) format and the PCI materials potentially greatly expand the usefulness of the Next Gen PET materials, which were developed over decades with NSF support. 

Intellectual Merit:

There were no instruments to formally assess the NGSS practice PCOI in pre-service teachers, so the instrument produced will be useful in assessing elementary teacher preparation.
